quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 4 Quiz 10
quiz.subtitle: 4.10: Environmental Impact
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: CFCs, Ozone Depletion, and Green Chemistry

questions.question: What are Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) commonly used for in industry due to their low reactivity?
options: Refrigerants, aerosol propellants, and solvents
Fertilizers and food additives
Fuel for internal combustion engines
Dyes for the textile industry
questions.explanation: CFCs were widely used because they are non-flammable, non-toxic, and very stable at ground level.

questions.question: In the stratosphere, what causes CFC molecules to break down and release chlorine radicals ($Cl\cdot$)?
options: High-energy Ultraviolet (UV) radiation
Reaction with oxygen gas ($O_{2}$)
Extreme cold temperatures
Collisions with meteor dust
questions.explanation: Short-wavelength UV light has enough energy to break the $C-Cl$ bond in the upper atmosphere through homolytic fission.

questions.question: What is the primary environmental role of the ozone layer ($O_{3}$) in the stratosphere?
options: Absorbing harmful UV-B and UV-C radiation
Trapping heat to prevent a global ice age
Reflecting radio waves back to Earth
Providing oxygen for high-altitude birds
questions.explanation: Ozone acts as a shield, preventing dangerous levels of ultraviolet radiation from reaching the Earth's surface.

questions.question: The destruction of ozone by chlorine radicals is described as a 'catalytic' process. Why?
options: A single chlorine radical can destroy thousands of ozone molecules
The reaction requires a platinum catalyst to occur
Chlorine is consumed in the first step and never released
The reaction only happens inside clouds
questions.explanation: The chlorine radical reacts with ozone to form $ClO\cdot$, which then reacts with atomic oxygen to regenerate the $Cl\cdot$ radical, allowing the cycle to repeat.

questions.question: Which international treaty was signed in 1987 to phase out the production of ozone-depleting substances?
options: The Montreal Protocol
The Kyoto Protocol
The Paris Agreement
The Geneva Convention
questions.explanation: The Montreal Protocol is considered one of the most successful environmental treaties, leading to a significant recovery of the ozone layer.

questions.question: Why are Hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) considered a 'greener' alternative to CFCs regarding ozone depletion?
options: They do not contain chlorine, so they cannot produce chlorine radicals
They react with ozone to produce more oxygen
They are much heavier and stay in the troposphere
They are made from biodegradable plant materials
questions.explanation: HFCs lack the $C-Cl$ bond. While they are potent greenhouse gases, they have an 'Ozone Depletion Potential' (ODP) of zero.

questions.question: What is a major environmental drawback of using certain haloalkanes like HFCs, even if they don't deplete ozone?
options: They have high Global Warming Potential (GWP)
They cause acid rain
They turn the ocean acidic
They lead to the overgrowth of algae
questions.explanation: HFCs are powerful greenhouse gases that contribute to climate change, leading to more recent regulations like the Kigali Amendment.

questions.question: The persistence of CFCs in the atmosphere is primarily due to:
options: The high strength and stability of the $C-Cl$ and $C-F$ bonds
Their ability to dissolve in rainwater
Their high reactivity with nitrogen gas
Their magnetic attraction to the North Pole
questions.explanation: CFCs are chemically inert in the lower atmosphere, allowing them to drift into the stratosphere over several decades.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the 'Green Chemistry' approach to haloalkanes?
options: Developing non-toxic, non-persistent, and biodegradable alternatives
Using more chlorine to ensure all ozone is removed
Burning all used refrigerants in open pits
Stopping the use of all chemicals entirely
questions.explanation: Green Chemistry focuses on the design of products and processes that minimize the use and generation of hazardous substances.

questions.question: What is the result of increased UV radiation reaching the Earth due to ozone thinning?
options: Increased rates of skin cancer and cataracts
A decrease in global temperatures
Improved growth of agricultural crops
A total loss of the Earth's atmosphere
questions.explanation: Excess UV radiation causes DNA damage in living tissues, leading to health issues in humans and damage to marine phytoplankton.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You understand the critical link between organic chemistry and environmental health.
scoreMessages.70: Great work. You have a solid grasp of the ozone depletion mechanism.
scoreMessages.50: Good progress. Review the specific role of the chlorine radical as a catalyst.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on why CFCs are stable on Earth but dangerous in the stratosphere.
